Idiot historians.  Winston Churchill was a longtime advocate of keeping India in the Empire.  He also had described Gandhi as "half-naked fakir" and a "seditious Middle Temple Lawyer."  FDR was constantly at odds with the imperialist Churchill (and the French) who wanted to keep their colonial possessions after WWII. (p.14).  Sir Richard Attenborough will be missed for that great movie and also for Chaplin, a man whom the USA government harried viciously.

No, climate models don't get the fine points right but they sure appear to have the big picture nailed. See, for example, http://blogs.agu.org/wildwildscience/2009/04/09/weather-climate-models-t... (Compare the Anthropogenic and Natural Forcings chart with the Natural Forcing Only chart.)

While I don't put much stock in detailed climate forecasts, detailed forecasts seem to me beside the point. I understand radiative transfer. CO2 is a very effective blanket. More CO2 emissions is the equivalent of piling on more blankets. As a result of anthropogenic CO2 emissions, the planet is going to retain a lot (A LOT!) more heat than it would otherwise. While climate models provide only low to moderate fidelity predictions of where that excess heat will end up (e.g., What fraction to the troposphere? What fraction to the upper levels of the ocean? What fraction to the land? What will happen to atmospheric and ocean circulation patterns?) I see no plausible scenario by which retaining all that excess heat plays out well for our species.

So long term climate models aren't high fidelity. So what? That they aren't makes me think of the scene from Ghostbusters where Gozer tells them to choose the form the Destructor and Ackroyd chooses the Stay Puft marshmallow man. Likewise, while don't know yet what the form of our Destructor will be, if we don't change course then sooner or later the choice will be made.

Michael S is willing to face reality, the Editorial Board not so much. Muslim allies? Really? The legendary peaceful moderate Muslims?

At the moment, we should rain death from the air and wait to see what other countries are willing to contribute.

This is smart advice.
Let us wait until we are attacked here at home, before positively identifying the attacker and THEN taking the nation to war.

We are fighting too many pre-emptive wars, afraid of the boogey man. We are the aggressors, since IS has done nothing to Americans, except those journalists who venture into contested territory during a wartime.

Tossing $250,000 missiles and $20,000 trucks is not a policy it's a sop to public opinion. We'll run out of Hellfire missiles before ISIS runs out of pickup trucks.

Calling on our allies - especially in Muslim countries - is also spin not policy. We have never gotten more than token military support from Muslin countries Most Western countries usually also send token support - if any - so the White House can claim a "coalition of the free".

Boots on the ground is the only way ISIS will be stopped and if we are too tired of war to engage well the Muslim world will have to fight it out or live with ISIS - at least until ISIS attacks us at home.
In other words, it's all relative.

I live near Pasadena and there are plenty of days in the summer I need to use the air conditioner, though I can turn it off at night, and also in the winter heat can often be needed in the early mornings and evenings.  Along the coast near L.A. you wouldn't need air conditioning, but that isn't true in the San Fernando and San Gabriel valleys.

Pasadena is at the base of the San Gabriel Mountains, you have a view of them from almost anywhere in the city. It is a short drive up the hills to the trees and creeks. The Mt. Wilson Observatory is also just up the hill.
Pasadena has cultural amenities close by, and one of the worlds great universities, Cal Tech, where football is just another activity. If the team wins it is considered a miracle.

There are great art museums, and the Huntington Library is just down the street a couple of miles. There are miles of mountain biking trails in the hills and the beach is not far away either. There is a big selection of very good restaurants where you can get more than barbeque. The Parkway Grill is one of my favorites. The Los Angeles Arboretum is also just east on Colorado Blvd, and if you like horse racing, Santa Anita is close by.

Traffic is bad, prices are high, and you wait overnight on the street to watch the Rose Parade, partying with others in January. Now how many people do you know who party on the main street in Ok City in January?

I have a friend who moved to Oklahoma City when GM transferred her husband from Pasadena, California. She talks about Pasadena all the time. I asked her what everybody here asks people from California. "Aren't the property taxes high there?" She said her property taxes were never near as high as her electrical bills are in Oklahoma.  It's 105 degrees here today and snow can be up to your knees in winter. There is never a break from heating and cooling. She said that in Pasadena they never had to use the air conditioner and they used the heater a couple of times every winter. So are places like Texas and Oklahoma cheaper? I know I could take a vacation on what I have to spend on cooling on these 105 degree humid days.

On a National basis, the root cause for this is that the use of "STATE'S RIGHTS" has allowed states like Texas to keep housing costs low, because, given tha actual lack of enough water to support high population density, they are using their current low density to keep housing prices low, even if they were not also doing it by chance because of keeping hourly and middle class wages low; for now.
I may be long gone when the water crisis hits, but those states will be the winers not the wineries eventually. As I recall, rural Texas counties have, due to local budget constraints, been forced to convert previously paved roads to gravel, because they couldn't afford the cost of new ashphalt. Go ahead, move to Texas, you probably will benefit economically, but your descendants? The only thing I'm sure of is that it will be sooner than everyone moving to Texas thinks. Water, not oil, is the truly critical resource for high density populations. California is showing that stress. Guess waht environmentally friendly critical resource NY has? I'll pay my taxes.

It's worth pointing out the housing construction also creates plenty of blue collar jobs, some of which are decently paid. New construction tends to be a lot more energy efficient than old houses and is also seismically safer. The coastal areas of California also have some of the lowest heating and cooling costs of anywhere in the country.

It is all very well to say that coastal cities are highly paid, but things don't look so good when you look at pay left over after housing costs. Texas is quite good in that regard, which is one reason it attracts people. Wages after housing expenses are almost the same as California. A few years ago I wrote a blog post with some charts on this topic.
http://schrodingerblog.blogspot.com/2011/07/california-versus-texas-part...
Another possibility, one not likely to be explored, is to declare neutrality in all Middle Eastern blood feuds and to mind our own business.
The British conquered and ruled India with about as many troops as ISIS had. All it requires is enough collaborators and the quiet acquiescence of the majority.

In Iraq, Sunni tribes and militias as well as former Ba'athists -- all alienated by mistreatment at the hands of the current Shiite government in Baghdad (and the political structure imposed by Paul Bremer and the USA) -- are supporting IS at this moment.

This will change when people living in areas captured by IS begin to experience the murder and other atrocities IS will visit upon them. There are not enough IS troops -- estimated to be somewhere south of 20,000 -- to control and pacify the wide swaths of territory they have seized.

The Americans need to stop pumping up the adrenaline with outrage over the IS horror show and start thinking intelligently about who needs to be at the table when inevitable negotiations to settle the chaos in the Middle East begin.

Defeating an enemy on the battlefield is only the beginning, as Donald Rumsfeld so graphically demonstrated when he bombed Iraq to kingdom come then failed to put enough boots on the ground to hold and heal the territory he won.

Vietnamization; i.e., "training" and arming proxies to implement U.S. foreign policy never works as planned: Iraq and Afghanistan are two glaring failures relevant in the present.

The USA has plenty of aircraft carriers and fighter bombers, all very impressive; but these are not the instruments required to sort through the web of complex enmities and alliances -- all temporary -- at play in the Middle East and find a way, assuming one even can be found, to deescalate these conflicts.

I have (just this month) become a full-time stay-at-home-mom and suddenly find myself with time to do things like cook inventive new dinners, but a diminished budget to do so. My husband and I have two children. Our son (2.5 years) seems to be on a meat/protein strike, although he loves everything else, and our daughter (5 months) is just about to begin solids. I'm always trying to find meals that are easily adaptable for the different tastes at our dinner table and for the different ingredients we already have in our kitchen (with that smaller budget in mind).

So many kids are so regulated today, and so over-scheduled, that I wonder if the children will have any kind of imagination or be able to make decisions on their own. And the schools are all teaching to the test now. I know everybody thinks their own era was better, but we got good educations in the 50s and 60s and we were free as birds all summer long, making up games because video games didn't exist. But that was before both moms and dads worked. Maybe there could be a career field for people to just hang around to make sure your kids don't get killed while they roam the countryside playing and exploring.

'Twas ever thus, Larry.
The same was true in 1962 when I visited friends in New York and inquired about living expenses there.
It may be said that living expenses are a hefty percentage less in Texas than in NYC (which is true, I'm sure) however, wages and salaries are correspondingly downsized; it's extremely difficult for those on the lower end of the pay scale to get ahead.
It's true, I've discovered, even for college professors (more so than high school educators).
A number of years ago, I discovered a college professor friend was delivering our morning newspaper.
He explained, over a cuppa coffee while collecting the monthly fee, that he paid child support from a previous marriage and his salary at the university didn't give enough leeway for him to provide adequately for his children and their needs.
If you get out into the West Texas more rural areas, the cost of living drops even further than in bigger cities such as Dallas, Houston, Austin or surrounding 'burbs.
Before anyone falls for Perry's siren call, they need to look at how far Texas has sunk in the last 20 years in demographics such as education, health services, etc.
Then consider: we've had 12 years of George, Jr., then 8 years of Rick Perry, his juvenile clone.
They've sucked the life out of the pleasure of living in Texas.
Texas isn't doing at all well, despite Perry's fairy tales; come to think of it, neither is the nation.

This might surprise you, but Houston probably has better air than Sacramento. The problem in California is the mountains, which trap the air and the pollution. In Texas the pollution just blows away over the plains.

Even with strict regulations and expensive pollution controls, air quality in much of California isn't great.
